Photographer James Oatway captured the attack on Mozambican Emmanuel Sithole that left him dead in broad daylight. The attackers looked like hardened thugs, and wanted one thing and that was to kill Emmanuel. Oatway tried to get as close as possible, conscious that the attackers were aware of his presence, but they finally moved on and left Sithole alone. Oatway's series of images of the ordeal landed on the front page of South Africa's Sunday Times under the headline, "Kill thy neighbor: Alex attack brings home SA's shame." Seven people have been killed in the latest round of xenophobic violence against poorer immigrants, many from South Africa's neighbors. Xenophobic attacks: How did we get here?

The Catholic Church in the United States has denounced the BBC drama Wolf Hall as a "prejudice-laden presentation of the past" after it was first aired in the country. The review attacked the six-part series as "a work of fiction that adopts a narrow, revisionist and anti-Catholic point of view toward the religious turmoil of the Tudor period in which it's set." The latest remarks echo criticisms voiced by clergy in the UK, who tore into the series for its "perverse" depictions of the historical characters when it first aired.

Craig Roberts, 36, was refused entry to the Post Office with his guide dog, Bruce, because the employee believed that Roberts' dog was not serviceable. Roberts was left feeling "angry and shocked," and has since filed a complaint with the Post Office. The Post Office has issued an apology for any distress caused.

The article discusses the violence that occurred Saturday night in Baltimore between protesters and police. Five police cars were damaged and twelve people were arrested. The majority of the protesters were peaceful, but a small group of agitators intervened and caused the violence. The family of Freddie Gray is angry about the way he was treated and the violence that occurred Saturday night is only adding to their pain.

Dave Roberts, a 50-year-old former TV and radio presenter, bungee jumped off the Transporter Bridge over the River Tees on Saturday for a children's charity. He survived the jump and said that it was 'fun and games' but that he is a serious mayoral candidate for the town. Mr Roberts' ancestor, Daniel McAllister, died after leaping off the bridge in 1913 for a drunken bet worth just a sixpence. Mr Roberts tracked down Mr McAllister's death certificate and found that he was a general labourer of Washington Street in Middlesbrough. He is running for mayor and said that he will be making a lot of serious points in the run-up to the election.

Nasa has unveiled a revolutionary type of wing that it says could save millions in air travel. The wing is able to morph itself like that of a bird to provide the same functionality as normal flaps, but with much less weight. It can also reportedly be used to increase fuel efficiency and even reduce noise on take-off and landing.

Manuel Pellegrini is under fire from Manchester City fans after their title race capitulation, but he insists he will not quit regardless of the pressure he has been under. Pellegrini's side face West Ham United at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday with their top four prospects hanging in the balance. If they miss out on the Champions League, Pellegrini's job could be in jeopardy.

1. Some fruits and seeds are high in antioxidants, which can have a wide range of health benefits.

2. Tart cherries, avocados, cranberries, blueberries, and pumpkin seeds are all high in antioxidants and are linked to a variety of health benefits.

3. Chia seeds are high in antioxidants, soluble fibre, and minerals, and are a good source of omega-3.

Gary Dahl, the creator of the Pet Rock, has died at age 78 in southern Oregon. The Pet Rock was a standard rock packaged around an amusing marketing strategy which became a brief but remarkably successful craze for several months in 1975. Although its popularity was short-lived, the Pet Rock was no more than a standard rock packaged around an amusing marketing strategy which divided opinion among those who look back on it with contempt, and those who admire his ability to sell it.

Eloise Aimee Parry, 21, died after taking the "diet pills" 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP). Five other people have died since 2008 after taking the pills, which are easy to purchase online and contain a toxic chemical used in pesticides and explosives. Mrs. Parry, the mother of Eloise, says that the drug is simple to concoct and that a student with a decent grade in A-level chemistry could work out how to synthesize it. Despite the dangers, the drug can be bought cheaply and easily online.

Eleven football fans have had their death sentences upheld after a retrial over a stadium riot in Egypt which left 74 people dead. The riot erupted in February 2012 when supporters of home team Al-Masry - from the canal city of Port Said - and Cairo's Al-Ahly clashed after an Egyptian league match between the two clubs. An appeals court ordered the retrial of 73 defendants last year after rejecting a lower court's verdict, which sentenced 21 people to death. The retrial has now resulted in the death sentences of eleven of the fans. The court will make a final decision on their fates, as well as those of the other defendants, on May 30.

Google revealed that the most popular questions typed into the search engine about 2016 presidential candidates were about candidates' ages and heights. The second-most popular question was 'Is Hillary Clinton a Democrat?' and the third-most popular question was about Rubio's height. Interest in Clinton and Rubio seemed to be on the rise as of Sunday after they said they were running.

The Army officer and his wife have admitted racially abusing hotel guests and workers after getting drunk at their own wedding reception. The couple were spared jail after a court heard that they were too drunk to remember what they had done at the Premier Inn at Stansted Airport. Assault: Aaron and Jade Badland have admitted assaulting a hotel worker after their wedding reception. Mr Badland, 24, a bomb disposal officer in the Engineering Regiment, was wearing his Army uniform during the drunken attack alongside his 29-year-old bride. Both newlyweds pleaded guilty to assault and were each ordered to carry out 80 hours of unpaid work, while Mrs Badland was also found guilty of racially aggravated harassment. Chelmsford Magistrates' Court heard that the couple got married in Malta last August, but held their wedding reception at Audley End, Essex in November. Afterwards they were staying at the Stansted branch of Premier Inn, where American guest David La Plante saw them abusing an Asian family. He told the court: 'Around the corner by some lifts we heard talk and the wife was making derogatory remarks to the family, calling them foreigners and asking if they had the Ebola virus. 'I positioned myself between her and the family and gave her a look saying "enough is enough".

The article discusses how the average American taxpayer gets a refund on their taxes, and how this has led to a happy spending spree. It also discusses how the tax system is increasingly a wage tax, with limited taxes on capital and limited deductions. This has made the tax system unpopular in the past, but it has become less of a problem in recent years because of the widespread use of free online filing.

The trip to Durminskoye Reserve in Khabarovsk lasts seven days in total with guests spending time in the wild environs inhabited by the last remaining Siberian tigers, and setting camera traps with the experts in the hope of catching an insight into the lives of these endangered predators. They will walk in the footsteps of the world’s biggest cats and spend time with Alexander Batalov, a frontline Russian conservationist who has spent the last 20 years of his life trying to protect the rare Siberian tiger. The facilities are described as 'basic' and guests are provided with a translator throughout the stay. The daily activity is to explore the Reserve in the hope of picking up tracks of the Siberian tigers that reside in this area.

Authorities are looking for Kamron Taylor, who escaped from a jail in Illinois early Wednesday morning after beating a correctional officer. Taylor is wanted for murder in connection with a botched robbery from 2009.

The article discusses a magazine from the 1930s that features a portrait of Adolf Hitler in lederhosen and knee-high socks. The magazine is comical and chilling because of the way Hitler is posed. After seeing the portrait, he never wore the cap again. The magazine also features poems and fawning descriptions of Hitler.

The study found that women who take hormone replacement therapy (HRT) continue to have a high risk of breast cancer years after stopping treatment. The risk is increased up to eight years after treatment is stopped. The study also found that the risk for invasive breast cancer falls for women taking oestrogen only treatment, but is increased for women taking combined HRT. The study urges caution, as the risk is different for each woman.

Rudi Austin was sent off in the first half for elbowing Ben Marshall off the ball and though Leeds resisted strongly until just after the hour mark, second-half goals by Tom Cairney, Jordan Rhodes and Jay Spearing settled the match. Blackburn extended their unbeaten away run to six matches while Leeds' five-game undefeated sequence came to an end.

Samantha Cameron is a 43-year-old British politician who is the wife of British Prime Minister David Cameron. She is known for her "cool" credentials, and this week she revealed her love of alternative group Poliça. Poliça's brand of psychedelic rock conjures up a world a far cry from her life in Downing Street and the Cotswolds, and their songs feature violent imagery. The video for the first single on the group's most recent album depicts androgynous-looking singer Channy Leaneagh subjecting her trussed-up alter ego to a violent assault. Blood spurts in all directions as she smashes her hands with a hammer, punches her in the face and finally waterboards her. Another unsettling song by the four-piece band from Minnesota, entitled Leading To Death, includes the lyric "I dream of you, oh my strangler." The tiny copper coin, which is smaller than a penny, dates from the Iron Age almost 2,300 years ago and suggests there were links between the south west of England and the Mediterranean. It was found in silt after the River Avon burst its banks between Bristol and Bath. The find suggests that the village of Saltford, where it was found, was on a major trade route long before Roman times.

Atletico Madrid manager Diego Simeone believes that English football needs to "wake up" after this season's poor showing in Europe. Chelsea, Arsenal, and Manchester City were all eliminated from the Champions League last 16 stage, while Everton were dumped out of the Europa League in the same round. Simeone believes that this season's failure should spark a response from the Premier League's top clubs, and he believes that Spain is still home to the two best teams in Europe - Wednesday night's opponents Real Madrid and Barcelona.

It also discusses the various rules that are in place at the Masters, such as the prohibition of cellphones, cameras, and knives.

Pascal Tessier, an 18-year-old Eagle Scout, has been hired as a summer camp leader by the Boy Scouts' Greater New York Councils. This is in contrast to the national scouting organization's ban on openly gay adult members, which Tessier has been a vocal advocate of. Tessier's hiring is seen as a watershed moment by advocates for letting gays participate in scouting.

Princess Eugenie of York, 25, was seen texting on her mobile as she navigated the concrete jungle on Thursday. The British royal, who is currently working in New York, showcased her hipster style for the second day in a row wearing a black bowler hat, black leather top and a black and cream miniskirt. Princess Eugenie, who recently turned 25, was engrossed in her phone after indulging in some retail therapy at Intermix in New York. Topshop striped zip through skirt.

David Cameron has warned voters that they have '11 days to save Britain', as he claimed Scottish nationalists 'don't want the country to succeed'. The Prime Minister said the Scottish National Party would prop up a minority Labour administration in the hope that the government would be a 'disaster' and bring forward its dream of independence. But Liberal Democrat Cabinet minster Danny Alexander accused the Prime Minister of 'playing with fire' by stirring up ill-feeling between Scotland and England in a way that would only fuel support for independence in next year's Scottish Parliament elections.

PepsiCo is dropping the sweetener aspartame from its popular drink in the U.S. in response to customer feedback. The reformulated drinks will now contain sucralose, another artificial sweetener commonly known as Splenda. Aspartame has been linked to a range of health problems, although research has shown it to be safe.

Emily Ratajkowski is a 23-year-old American model and actress who has become well-known for her role in the steamy music video for Robin Thicke's song, "Blurred Lines." Emily's figure has become a popular topic of discussion, with many people eager to emulate her curves. Emily's diet and exercise regimen is said to include meat and occasional indulgences, hiking, yoga, and cooking using fresh ingredients. Emily has spoken out about the objectification of both women and men, and insists that sexuality should be empowering for women.

Chelsea secured the Premier League title with a late 87th minute winner against QPR. Thibaut Courtois was the stand-out performer for the home side, with several crucial saves keeping the QPR side at bay. Cesc Fabregas was the hero of the match, scoring the winner in the 87th minute.

Eight-year-old Piper died in a horrific car accident in New South Wales on Saturday. She was traveling with her mother, two brothers, and grandmother when their Holden Astra aqua-planed, spun out of control and ended up on the other side of the road. Piper's grandmother was also in the vehicle at the time of the accident. The crash also left passengers in the ute that collided with the Astra with severe injuries. Warwick Milham arrived at the scene after hearing his wife and daughter were involved in the crash. Glenda Milham suffered a fractured neck while Michelle had broken bones. 'It was a horrendous scene. I wouldn't wish it upon anybody,' Mr Milham told 9News. With the crash claiming Piper's life, the national Easter long weekend death toll now stands at 10.

Daniel Williams, an office worker from Toronto, filmed himself doing everything from sealing envelopes and sending emails to making cups and coffee and going to the bathroom, before editing all of the clips together to offer an action-packed perspective of his regular daily life. The video, which is titled 'Boring Office Job GoPro Commercial', has clearly struck a chord with people working in similar jobs around the globe, with the video already attracting an impressive three million views since being uploaded to YouTube last week.

Michael Gridley, 26, was jailed for a year after orchestrating a scam to steal £15,000 of goods from the Asda in Basildon, Essex. An Asda manager orchestrated a scam that used the supermarket's own delivery service to steal goods worth more than £15,000 - then managed to land a job at Lidl after he was sacked. Gridley, who was former home shopping manager of the store, was sentenced to 12 months for his leading role in a conspiracy to steal £15,852.46 worth of goods between November 2013 and April last year. The court heard that Reed and another defendant James Munyard had been pressured into taking part in the scam by Gridley, who was their superior.

German detectives are investigating links between the Hatton Garden gems heist and a strikingly similar raid on a Berlin bank two years ago. In January 2013, thieves broke into the Volksbank in Steglitz, Berlin, and stole jewels and cash worth up to £8.3 million. The London robbers may have carried out the Steglitz robbery just two years earlier, and German detectives are keen to find out whether any DNA was recovered from the scene of the Easter weekend raid and, crucially, whether it matches forensic samples found in a tunnel used in the Berlin robbery.

Jimmy Kimmel Live aired a parody of Manny Pacquiao's song "Lalaban Ako Para Sa Filipino" which was written and recorded by Pacquiao specifically for his walk-out music for his fight against Floyd Mayweather. Pacquiao was impressed and amused by the song and thanked Kimmel on Twitter. Pacquiao's song translates to English as "I Will Fight For The Fillipino" and will be blasted through the MGM Grand Arena on May 2 before he bids to end Mayweather's 47-fight unbeaten run.

Kevin Pietersen backs former team-mate Michael Vaughan as the right man to 'change the brand of cricket currently being played' in England, and believes Vaughan has the credentials to replace him as captain. Vaughan has previously concentrated on his media duties but is believed to be open to the role of director of England cricket. Downton's troubled reign was defined by the decision to martyr Pietersen after the 2013/14 Ashes, and the ECB board met at Lord's on Thursday but there was no official word on the recruitment process.

The EU has abolished milk quotas, which is expected to lead to a price war over the cost of milk. This will be particularly difficult for smaller family businesses. British farmers are likely to find the price they are paid by supermarkets is driven down, which will be particularly difficult for them.

- Andy Silvester, campaign director, said: 'Everyone should play by the rules, and that means paying back on time if HMRC say so. 'However, the real moral of this story is that we desperately need to simplify the tax code to get rid of the loopholes that those with clever accountants can drive a Take That tour bus through.
- Politicians make an awful lot of noise about tax evasion and avoidance but are addressing the symptom rather than the cause.

Detective Patrick Cherry of the NYPD's joint terrorism task force was captured on video ranting at an Uber driver. Cherry is now under investigation by the Civilian Complaint Review Board following a complaint of 'discourtesy'. President of the Detectives Endowment Association said Detective Cherry had been visiting his colleague Detective Harry Hill who had recently had a heart attack while undergoing surgery and was very stressed.

Michelle Keegan has just released her new Lipsy fashion range. The star, who is getting married this year, has been hard at work in the design studio to bring fans exactly what they want for the warmer months. The actress and model shows off her natural beauty posing by the ocean in the summer shoot. The designer has been chanelling her passion for fashion into Lipsy ranges for several seasons now and her success shows no sign of abating.

Raheem Sterling rejected a Liverpool contract offer of £100,000-a-week, saying he is focusing on his football. Sterling says it is not about money, only about trophies - so can Liverpool afford to not win any this season? Sterling says players come and go, and that he holds all the power in this situation.

The article discusses an optical illusion called "Marilyn Einstein" which is created by superimposing a blurry picture of Marilyn Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein drawn in fine lines. Features with a high spatial frequency (Einstein) are only visible when you're viewing them close up, and those with low spatial frequencies (Monroe) are only visible from further away. Combining pictures of the two produces a single image which changes when the viewer moves closer or farther away from the screen. This classic optical illusion was created several years ago by neuroscientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In a recent video, AsapScience highlighted the process behind the trick, which can also be seen in a still image by anyone if they move closer and then farther away from the screen. Dr Oliva's group says these images not only reveal vision problems, but can also highlight how the brain processes information.

Ian Rogers owns nine haunted dolls all of which he says contain their own personality. Ian's favorite doll is Annabel, who he thinks is haunted by a seven-year-old girl who drowned. Ian, who is single, and a vehicle image inspector, from Leicester, says that his obsession with the supernatural began at a very young age. His dolls were previously shared between Ian and his sister, but his sister wanted to get rid of them after they started causing her too much mischief, for example hiding her keys. However Ian says that he hasn't been put off in the slightest and is even looking at investing in other supernatural souvenirs.

Celtic striker Leigh Griffiths scored a hat-trick in a comeback Premiership win over Kilmarnock, and manager Ronny Deila hailed his ultimate impact. Griffiths' desire to prove him wrong should serve as an example to any player left out of his starting XI. Griffiths took just 19 minutes to score a treble that takes Celtic ever closer to a clean sweep of domestic honours.

The Ipsos Mori poll found that a referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union was more popular with voters north of the border than another independence ballot. The idea of having another referendum on Scotland's future in the UK before 2020 was ranked 19th on a list of 23 policies presented to voters. It comes after Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon last night refused to rule out staging a second independence vote if the SNP wins the 2016 Holyrood elections.

The BBC filled more than half its election TV debate audience with left-leaning voters, some of whom were brought in from Scotland and Wales. The audience at the filming of Thursday night’s debate in Westminster repeatedly cheered calls for more public spending and strong defences of immigration. When Ukip leader Nigel Farage interjected and said they were prejudiced, ‘even by the Left-wing standards of the BBC’, the audience only booed him further.

Marc Carn, 29, from Plymouth, Devon, went missing during a stag do in Barcelona and was found safe and well this afternoon after walking for two days to get back to the city. His family was worried that he would miss the first birthday of his twins, Freddie and Stanley.

The article tells the story of a three-year-old chimpanzee who was rescued after she was found in a tiny wooden box cowering from the animal traffickers who killed her mother. The traffickers had kept the terrified three-year-old in the box for two weeks. And the men had been trying to find a buyer on the lucrative black market when they were stopped at a check point trying to cross into Sierra Leone from Guinea, in west Africa, last week. The chimpanzee was accepted by a sanctuary and is now looking forward to a second chance.

The researchers at Massachusetts Institute of Technology have created an algorithm that can tell how effectively someone is striking a keypad. This information can be used to distinguish between typing done in the middle of the night, when sleep deprivation impairs motor skills, and typing performed when fully rested. The study is based on the premise that 'there might be hidden information in the way that we type,' says Ian Butterworth, one of researchers. This strategy could be used to evaluate patients with other diseases that affect motor skills, such as Parkinson's disease. Preliminary results from a study of about two dozen Parkinson's patients suggest that the researchers' algorithm for analysing keystrokes can also distinguish people who have the disease from those who don't.

David Axelrod, a US political adviser hired by Labour leader Ed Miliband, has admitted he is not resident for tax purposes in the UK, and pays taxes in the US. Miliband's crackdown on non-doms last week has raised concerns among Labour frontbenchers that despite his high salary, Axelrod has been "invisible" ahead of polling day.

The article tells the story of a 46-year-old man, Edwin "Jock" Mee, who is accused of raping two female cadets at a military base in south London. Mee is also accused of sexually assaulting 11 other cadets, many of whom were young black women. The cousin of one of Mee's alleged victims told the court that she called the sergeant after becoming concerned he wanted to start a sexual relationship with the cadet. When Mee was asked to repeat what he had said, the witness explained how he went quiet and then hung up. Mee has denied all the charges against him. The trial, which is expected to run for six weeks, continues.

The article tells of the criminal probe into the death of two members of a family by their GP, Dr Rory Lyons. The cousins Karen and Colin Cosheril died after being patients of Dr Lyons, and the investigation uncovered three more deaths of concern - including that of retired stonemason Colin Cosheril. The family liaison officers have been sent to the island to help relatives of the deceased. Dr Lyons has been suspended by the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service and his surgery raided.

The article discusses the recent rainstorm that has hit Southern California, which is much needed after years of drought. The storm brought light but necessary rainfall across a region that has been experiencing extreme drought conditions. Thousands were without power for several hours because of the storm, and the Los Angeles Dodgers had a rare rain delay on the second day of the season.

The disabled community has a lot of complaints about able-bodied people who think they are being supportive, but often end up being the opposite. One common complaint is people insisting they 'help', and not taking no for an answer. Another common complaint is people taking charge of their wheelchair. Another is people insisting they 'know more about treatments than the disabled person'. Last but not least, whatever you do, don't bring religion into it.

Atletico Madrid supporters have stopped fretting about departures because they have good reason to be confident in the people that run the club and their ability to find adequate replacements. In goal Sergio Asenjo became David De Gea, became Thibaut Courtois, who looks to have become Jan Oblak. Playmaker Diego Ribas became Arda Turan. While centre-forward Diego Forlan became Sergio Aguero, became Radamel Falcao, became Diego Costa who has now become that bloodied battering-ram Mario Mandzukic. The secret of their success is often exactly that – a secret.

The owl, which is part of a set of three that had sat on a shelf in the pub lounge, was "kidnapped" from the Admiral Rodney in Nottingham last month and has been jetting around the world since then. The owl has been pictured sunning itself on a beach, taking a ride on the back of a camel, and sitting on a bar next to a pint of Guinness.

Anuradha Koirala, the 2010 CNN Hero of the Year, has a rehabilitation center in Kathmandu that is home to 425 young women and girls. The aftershocks have made it difficult for them to sleep, and they are now living on the ground in a nearby field. Anuradha Koirala's group is relying on bottled water and is now rationing food. Pushpa Basnet, the 45 children she cares for, and the children at her HIV/AIDS hospice, all had to evacuate their residence in the earthquake. The wall of Koirala's HIV/AIDS hospice has crumbled, and the staff is afraid it might fall down. The public has been warned not to use the main water line due to risk of cholera.

The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has backed the royals' choice of private care for Kate's second birth. Private healthcare is a total matter of choice for people - what they use and where they have their babies. The NHS is superb and I've seen that in my own life in so many different ways, but I believe in choice, I believe in people being able to do what they want to do. As I say, I've only got one thought about the royal baby which is a happy and healthy arrival.

Ryan Hardie made his full Rangers debut and scored a brace in a 3-1 win over Dumbarton. The 18-year-old had made just four substitute appearances before facing the Sons at the Dumbarton Stadium, but his double put Rangers in command after they fell behind to Mark Wilson's second-minute opener. Stuart McCall promised his students from the Murray Park youth ranks they would be given their chance to impress when he took over last month, and he stayed good to his word as Hardie and winger Tom Walsh came in to replace Kenny Miller and Dean Shiels. Mohammad Liaqat, a 34-year-old Muslim man, became angry after Mount Carmel School headteacher Xavier Bowers banned Muslim pupils from growing beards. Liaqat then went to another school, where he assaulted the headteacher after he was asked to leave. Liaqat was found guilty of one count of assault and five counts of racially or religiously aggravated behaviour. He was remanded into custody and will be sentenced in June.

The article discusses how Australian researchers have developed a drone running companion called Joggobot. The goal of the study was to see if a drone could motivate a runner to keep their pace up, and provide a companion that helped them stay fit. In this experiment, the quadcopters were programmed to follow a set path and speed, which the joggers also followed. The majority of the participants found the drone to be a good ‘pace keeper’, especially on straight sections of their run. There were some concerns from the runners, though; occasionally the quadcopter would deviate from its path, leading them to question their safety. And it also wobbled in the wind, which one runner likened to it having a personality of its own. One also noted that they ‘felt a bit awkward with a camera on my head and jogging with a robot.’ But they added: ‘I’m jogging with a robot, and people think it’s rad.’ Ultimately, the researchers think their study could help design flying robots that support joggers, and it could even be used for other sports as well such as cycling, cross-country skiing, rowing or even fun runs.

The article discusses how Bristol City are inching closer to promotion to the Football League, and how they prevented Preston from making any ground on them in the top two. The article also discusses how Swindon's win over Peterborough means Steve Cotterill will have to wait until Tuesday to finish the job of returning to the Championship.

President Barack Obama defended a framework nuclear agreement with Iran as a 'once-in-a-lifetime opportunity' to prevent a bomb and bring longer-term stability to the Middle East. He acknowledged that his pursuit of diplomacy with Tehran has caused strain with the close ally, but insisted that the nuclear talks were the most effective way to keep Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. The president looked forward to 'a new era' of relations with Iran, but cautioned that there would be 'real political difficulties' in implementing an agreement.

The author describes how they rented a boat and pottered about at will on the Greek island of Skopelos. The island has a relaxed, offbeat vibe that plays out in the pretty port of Chora. The boat owners gave them a second anchor and assured them they would retrieve the original anchor. This generosity of spirit set the tone for their week on the island. The author enjoyed exploring the coastline and the island's many scenic spots.

The Liberal Democrats are promising to spend more on education than any other party, and they are doing this in order to win over Conservative voters. The party is also promising to raise taxes on the rich, to end the use of nuclear and coal power stations, to ban fracking, and to raise rail fares.

New York teen Daria Rose has been accepted to seven Ivy League schools, including Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Dartmouth, University of Pennsylvania, Cornell, and Brown. Rose, who lost everything in Hurricane Sandy, immersed herself in her studies after her family lost their home. Her frequent moves made finishing school work difficult, but she never gave up on her dream of attending an Ivy League school. Her essay about her experience helped her secure a spot in Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Dartmouth, University of Pennsylvania, Cornell, and Brown.

Fathers in Sweden are able to take 480 days of parental leave, with 390 of them paid at 80% of income. If the 60 daddy days aren't used, they are lost, reducing the maximum leave to 420 days. Sweden also created a "gender equality bonus": the more days that parents share the leave equally, they get a bonus that could total up to 1,500 euros, or $1,649. The idea is for both parents to share the joys and struggles of raising infants, but in reality, only 12% of Swedish couples equally share the 480 days of leave. The fathers have become more understanding of their wives and even their own mothers, and some are now considering a career change to accommodate their parenthood. Johan Bavman is looking for a total of 60 fathers to photograph, to culminate in an exhibition and a book.

Laura Wells, a plus-size model, spoke to Australian Women's Weekly about the extreme dieting measures taken by her model roommates to prepare for Fashion Week. The size 14 beauty lived with a group of standard 'skinnier' models during her stint working in New York, and says that their agents instructed them to stick to a diet of 'one cracker and a couple of glasses of water'. The measures taken by the model roommates are extreme and unhealthy, not only for their body but mentally as well. Laura's comments come days after France passed legislation banning excessively thin models from participating in Paris Fashion Week. Agents and fashion houses that hire them could also face fines under the new law, which was passed on April 3.

Raheem Sterling is caught on camera smoking a shisha pipe, which is a popular fad among young people. He recently snubbed a new £100,000-a-week contract offer from the Merseyside club, and some Liverpool fans are concerned about his safety. Depending on the result of the Manchester derby on Sunday, Sterling and his team-mates could close the gap between themselves and fourth placed Manchester City to four points.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, battled cancer using a superhero mask to help him through his treatment. After his story made headlines around the world, Nickelodeon even sent him a box full of Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas. Harley is now cancer-free and will undergo regular check-ups to make sure he stays free of the disease.

Raheem Sterling has been the subject of criticism from Liverpool fans and the media over his contract stand-off, but the 20-year-old insists he is immune to the negative comments. Sterling has set targets for himself and is hoping to improve his performances in the last few games of the season.

Cecil Hamilton-Miller was a British solicitor and former Mayor of Glastonbury who was responsible for the convictions of 31 concentration camp guards in 1945, including several key Belsen figures, such as camp commander Josef Kramer and Dr Fritz Klein. Mr Hamilton-Miller struggled to talk about the horrors he witnessed during the holocaust or the role he played after the liberation of Belsen, his family has said today.

The kidnapping of nearly 300 schoolgirls by a jihadist group in Nigeria one year ago remains a crime almost too horrifying to comprehend. Hundreds of teenaged girls, just finishing school, destined perhaps for significant achievement - kidnapped, never to be seen again. President-elect Muhammadu Buhari has pledged an aggressive effort to wipe out the group, but much remains unchanged, as Boko Haram still controls swathes of northeastern Nigeria and continues to kill in large numbers.

The study found that bird populations have dramatically declined in Fukushima, with one breed in particular having plummeted from several hundred to just a few dozen today. Radiation levels in the region have started to fall, but the negative effects of the accident on birds are actually increasing. The team is hoping to get information on what the future holds for Fukushima from the Chernobyl site, which was the scene of a devastating release of radioactive materials in 1986.

Ian Poulter, a professional golfer, often uses acupuncture to recover from strains and injuries that come with the sport. English golfer Paul Casey also uses acupuncture to recover from injuries. Floyd Mayweather Jnr. recently shared a video of himself receiving a SubZero recovery cool down in Las Vegas ahead of his $300million mega-fight with Manny Pacquiao. The treatment known as kriotherapy (or cryotherapy) involves exposing the body to freezing temperatures of -200C for between 1-3minutes to assist muscle recovery. Kriotherapy has also been used by the Wales rugby union team as well as Tottenham players including Andros Townsend, Christian Eriksen and Jan Vertonghen - while Real Madrid superstar has had his own 'ice chamber' installed at home. Head of sports science at Manchester City (and formerly with Spurs), Dr Sam Erith, has said: 'Kriotherapy means you can train more, to get fitter more quickly. With the players who have been rehabilitating, they've been training three times a day.' Alternative treatments including that used by NBA player Amar'e Stoudemire are even stranger. The father and two sons who accosted pensioners with dementia in the street asking for payment for roof repairs they hadn't done have been jailed for a total of eight years. The trio would drive alongside their victims in a silver Mercedes C200 until they got close to their house, before jumping out and telling them they had come to collect payment for roofing work. Jesse Webb, 19, was due to be sentenced with his father and brother, but went on the run.

Per Mertesacker, a German defender, says that if Jurgen Klopp, a German coach, decides to continue his career in England, he would be a good fit for the Premier League. Klopp, 47, announced earlier this week that he will end his seven-year stint at Borussia Dortmund when the current season draws to a close, prompting speculation that he could head for the Premier League. Manchester City have already indicated that a man who has also been linked with Manchester United and Arsenal in the past, is not in their sights, but Germany international Mertesacker insists Klopp would be a good fit in the English top flight.

Prasanna 'Nick' Arulchelvam, 34, died after he fell from a van while chasing a gang of thieves. A courageous shopkeeper was killed when he made a desperate attempt to stop a gang of thieves who had broken into his van in a cash and carry car park. Prasanna 'Nick' Arulchelvam ran and jumped through an open side door of their van, but was pushed out and hit the ground as the vehicle sped away. A customer in the Costco car park in Watford where the incident happened reported hearing a 'nasty crunch' as the 34-year-old's head hit the ground. Today, the man who pushed Mr Prasanna to his death was jailed for 11 years after admitting all he wanted was 'a few cheap packets of cigarettes'.

Iran's defiance to halt its controversial nuclear program has defined Khameni's era. He has defied the West in the face of increasing economic pressure. Iran claims that its program is peaceful, but Khamenei's refusal to end uranium enrichment activities -- a process that can lead to making nuclear fuel as well as nuclear bombs -- has landed the country under crippling sanctions. The standoff with the West has stretched longer than the war. The agreement reached in Lausanne, Switzerland, however, marks a new chapter in the history of the country. If Iran can finalize a deal by June with the United States and its P5+1 partners, international investors, including Americans, would be able to invest in Iran for the first time in decades.

William Shatner, who played Captain James T. Kirk on the popular TV show "Star Trek," has proposed a radical solution to California's ongoing drought disaster: building a pipeline from Seattle to bring water to the state. However, some experts have said the proposal is illogical and would require a lot of hurdles to be overcome. If the campaign is successful, Mr. Shatner says he will give the money he raises to a politician.

Alastair Cook is England's leading century maker despite his recent failure to score a Test century. The decision of Graves and Harrison to sack Paul Downton as managing director and announce that they are looking for a new ‘supremo’ to replace him has placed Cook and Peter Moores under more pressure than ever. If England really do want a change at the top then it must come sooner rather than later, particularly if, as expected, they would bypass vice-captain Ian Bell and go straight to the man who now seems the heir apparent, Joe Root.

Jason Holder did well in the second Test against England, managing to score 103 not out. This is an encouraging sign for the new West Indies coach, Phil Simmons, as it shows that he is trying to instill discipline and character in his team. This is a difficult format of cricket and it takes a lot of effort and dedication to succeed in it.

Andre Gignac claims to have found what he believes to be a bunker on the red planet, with armed people peering out of its windows. Some scientists believe that sightings such as this are simple cases of pareidolia, or the brain's response to seeing faces and other significant objects in random places.

A couple spent two years battling the council over a £2.20 parking ticket they say blew off their dashboard - and ended up having to pay £400. The couple explained to the authorities what had happened but were not let off the fine. adamant they would not pay it, the O'Byrne's exchanged a number of letters with the council over the next two years - with the row escalating from an initial £25 fine to bailiffs knocking on their door and demanding £400. Mr O'Byrne, from Southsea in Portsmouth, Hampshire, was forced to pay the sum to Chichester District Council after the incident in a car park in Chichester, West Sussex. Mr O'Byrne, a self-employed marketing consultant, said: 'We parked in a marked bay and purchased a ticket. 'As this was the first time we'd taken our first child out of the house it was all a bit of an ordeal getting her and the buggy out, out of the way of other traffic. 'In my haste I failed to attach the ticket firmly to the inside of the windscreen. Manchester City midfielder James Milner is a free agent this summer and could leave the club. Swansea goalkeeper Gerhard Tremmel, 36, is the understudy for Lukasz Fabianski and has done well in the cups. England's first-choice right-back at the World Cup, Glen Johnson, is on a bumper deal at Liverpool and there seems to be little appetite to keep him on the books. Centre-back Kolo Toure, 34, has been inconsistent and has made some terrible gaffes at Liverpool. Centre-back Ron Vlaar, 30, is still to extend his contract at Villa and could leave the club. Everton left-back Luke Garbutt, 21, faces a big battle to displace Leighton Baines. Right wing James Milner, 53 England caps, is still wanted by Manchester United. Newcastle left-back Jonas Gutierrez, 32, battled back from testicular cancer to return to the Newcastle squad last month.

The vaccine being developed to help prevent the recurrence of prostate cancer is made from pieces of a protein called TARP that is found in about 95% of prostate cancers. Animal studies have shown that the protein can effectively stimulate the immune system to attack the cancer. The vaccine is being tested as a way to treat cancer that has returned, but if successful, could be used as a first line treatment for prostate and potentially breast cancer in the future.

The Green party has released a new election advert featuring David Cameron, Nick Clegg, Ed Miliband and Nigel Farage forming a bizarre pro-austerity boyband. The video is designed to show that despite their claims to the contrary, the Tories, Lib Dems, Labour and Ukip are all singing the same tune on cuts, public services and immigration. The video begins with 'David Cameron' playing a white grand piano, with 'Ed Miliband' looking on. It sees Mr Cameron entering a polling booth and telling voters how 'a vote for me's the same as a vote for any of us guys'. The advert is designed to show that despite their claims to the contrary, the Tories, Lib Dems, Labour and Ukip are all singing the same tune on cuts, public services and immigration. The song, Change The Tune, features comedians playing the four party leaders forming a boyband called Coalition.

Mindy Kaling's brother Vijay Chokalingam recently revealed a project of his own, and while it has been getting a lot of attention, it hasn't generated quite as many laughs — either from observers or from his famous sibling, who told him it brought "shame upon their family." Chokalingam had spent his college years as a "hard-partying frat boy," and achieved a less than stunning 3.1 GPA. Upon facing graduation and exploring his med school options, he realized that fellow Indian-Americans with his grades were getting turned down from the universities of his choice, but that "black, Hispanic, and Native American applicants with my grades and test scores were much more likely to gain acceptance." This revelation led him to make the decision to pose as a black man, both to "dramatically improve" his chances of admission, and to illustrate the unfair advantage that blacks and other underrepresented minorities receive when applying to prestigious schools. To accomplish this goal, Chokalingam shaved his head of its naturally wavy black locks, trimmed his "long Indian-American eyelashes," checked "black" under the optional race/ethnicity declaration and submitted his application to 14 schools under his childhood nickname "JoJo." The article discusses how sweet potatoes have been found to contain 'foreign DNA' that has been transferred from bacteria. This foreign DNA is similar to the artificial process induced by humans, but the difference pointed out by the researchers is that we can control the man-made process, while the natural process is out of our hands.

The Taliban's "Cultural Commission" released a biography of Mullah Mohammed Omar, the reclusive leader of the Taliban, in an apparent effort to dispel rumors of his death. The biography offers a description of Omar's daily work schedule, which begins with prayers, study of the Quran, and then delivering "orders in a specific way to his Jihadi commanders." The publication also seeks to fill in some of the gaps about the militant's early years, including the detail that his "preferred weapon of choice" was the RPG-7, a rocket-propelled grenade.

Helen Dunn, 78, was surprised to find her cover images for vintage lads' mag Span, when she opened the Sunday Mercury newspaper. The cover image shows Dunn, who was just 17 years old at the time, perched seductively on a stool with her legs slightly crossed. Dunn went on to marry Manchester United footballer Alan Dunn, just three years after the shoot. The grandmother recalls her modelling days with a fondness, and remembers the shoot clearly.

Tony Blair is being criticized for his comments in a Newsweek article in which he said he wanted to create a "cadre" of former leaders to advise governments. Some people are calling him a "megalomaniac" for his ideas, which they say are reminiscent of a benevolent dictatorship. Blair has been working as a peace envoy while picking up international consultancy work that earns him millions of pounds a year, and he says he plans to stay active in both politics and business well into his 90s.

After an employee clicked on a link in an email, hackers took control of the Scooter's Coffee Facebook page and flooded it with pornography. After trying to contact officials at Facebook with limited success, it was not until a day later that the company managed to kick the hacker out, and regain control of the account. Delta Air Lines and Crayola were also affected in similar attacks in January.

Adam McBurney, a young Irish rugby player, escaped serious injury when his home was targeted by a gunman who fired multiple bullets through his windows. The gunman is still at large and police are appealing for witnesses. If McBurney had been in the home, he could have been killed. McBurney, who has been capped for the Ireland Under-20s and recently played in their Six Nations campaign, lives at the home with his brother Shane, 20.

The Dove One Beautiful Thought campaign encouraged women to be kinder to themselves and each other by using a script that contained only the original notes written by the women. The actresses who played the parts of the women in the campaign were shocked by the harsh comments that were written in the notebooks. Some of the comments echoed the kind of schoolyard bullying we would frown upon.

Christian Benteke saved Aston Villa from relegation with a hat-trick against QPR. Villa are now three points above the relegation zone and safe from the drop. Benteke has been in good form under new manager Tim Sherwood and the boss hopes he can maintain his form to keep Villa up.

Gareth Huw Davies enjoys the new stability on the teardrop-shaped island in the Indian Ocean, where the holiday industry is recovering, and expanding with a crop of smart new hotels, after the dual torment of a tsunami and a bitter civil war. The modern Seema Malaka temple, Colombo, Sri Lanka. The temple floats on Colombo's Beira Lake.

Serendib is the island’s ancient name. It happens everywhere. On one of my early starts for an excursion, serendipity was seeing dozens of candles flickering in the dense dark outside a Buddhist temple. Then a schoolgirl in brilliant white uniform striding through the dawn mists along a levee between paddy fields, while an equally white egret paced daintily in the water. Or an old lady, knee-deep in a swamp picking blue water lilies, the national flower. And everywhere, games of impromptu cricket, with a stick for a bat and a plastic drum for a wicket, on bare mud patches, in gardens, on roads.

England's captain Alastair Cook is under pressure after the team's failure to win the first Test. However, coach Peter Moores remains steadfast in his backing for Cook and is adamant he will turn things around in Grenada and Barbados. Cook is facing swing in the first Test and Moores is hopeful that Moeen Ali, who is joining the team in Grenada, can help him. The pressure is increased on Moores, Cook, and England by new ECB chairman Colin Graves' description of West Indies as "mediocre" before this series. However, Moores insists that England has only one focus and that is to win this series.

Janet Muller, a 21-year-old university student from Germany, was last seen on CCTV at 10:33pm on March 12 in a subway in Portslade, East Sussex. The next day, her body was found in the boot of a burning car in Ifield, near Crawley, West Sussex. Christopher Jeffrey-Shaw, 26, of Lakeside, Beckenham, London, has been charged with her murder and will appear at Guildford Crown Court for a preliminary hearing on April 9.

The couple who decorated their home with sentimental trinkets and tributes that were looted from graves have been banned from cemeteries indefinitely. Sean Jefferson, 45, and Elizabeth Jowitt, 37, admitted handling stolen goods at York Magistrates' Court after decorating their flat with items such as lanterns, wreaths, trinkets and homemade gifts. The couple's actions were eventually discovered when a relative of one of the victims noticed a heart-shaped wreath which was meant for her mother hanging in their home. She contacted police and a raid found further items such as love heart ornaments, rosary beads and homemade gifts being used as decorations. Jefferson and Jowitt pleaded guilty to two counts of handling stolen goods and were given a 47-week curfew and a restraining order banning them from cemeteries in the York area indefinitely. Kia Carlton, 26, said she had already felt suicidal after her daughter Telan died in her cot when she was just 11-months-old and said the disappearance of items from her daughter's grave was 'distressing'.
